newsitem.title: FRANCE: Second time lucky for Cuban-born writer in France.
newsitem.headline: Second time lucky for Cuban-born writer in France.

text.p: Cuban-born writer Eduardo Manet won France's Interallie prize on Tuesday, a week after missing the country's top Goncourt literary award by a whisker.

Manet won the last of the French literary season's prizes for "Rhapsodie Cubaine" (Cuban Rhapsody), a novel about a wealthy Cuban family going into exile in Miami after President Fidel Castro's 1959 Communist revolution.
Manet, who himself left Cuba and became a French citizen in 1979, tells how the Sargats family's son Julian gradually blends into American society while his mother sinks into alcoholism.
But Julian, torn between the English and Spanish languages and haunted by a secret nostalgia for Havana, remains "a drifting algae, a foreign species which cannot take root anywhere".
The Goncourt jury last week was split five-to-five between Manet and French writer Pascale Roze's "Le Chasseur Zero" (Fighter Zero). The president of the jury cast the deciding vote for Roze.
